title: What's News: World-Wide — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 1, 2019).

Pompeo was among administration officials who listened in on the July 25 phone call between Trump and Ukrainian President Zelensky, a senior State Department official said.

Bolton criticized U.S. policy on North Korea in his first public-speaking engagement since leaving his post as Trump's national security adviser.

U.S. authorities unsealed a criminal complaint alleging a California tour guide worked as a spy for Chinese intelligence.

The Treasury Department issued new sanctions against the Russian accused of orchestrating a campaign for Moscow to influence the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

Xi presided over a military parade marking the 70th anniversary of Communist Chinese rule, while Hong Kong braced for another round of protests.

Questions about Johnson's past threatened to overshadow the annual gathering of his party as the British leader seeks to rally support for his Brexit strategy.

California's governor signed a bill allowing college athletes in the state to earn endorsement and sponsorship money.

Alberto Salazar, the Nike-backed distance-running coach, received a four-year ban for orchestrating and facilitating prohibited doping.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 01, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
